Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The smell of roast chicken filled the house as I set the table, my stepmom calling everyone for dinner. It was one of those rare evenings when all of us—my stepbrother, stepsister, and I—were together, and I knew how much it meant to her. I tried to push aside the awkwardness that sometimes lingered between us, focusing on being present, laughing at my stepbrother’s jokes, and helping my little stepsister with her plate. Just as we sat down, my phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning. The sirens outside wailed, and I glanced out the window to see water creeping up the street. I remembered the city’s emergency alert: able-bodied citizens should help neighbors evacuate and check on the elderly. My heart pounded. I could see Mrs. Lee, our elderly neighbor, peering anxiously from her porch. My family looked at me, expecting me to stay, to be part of this rare, fragile togetherness. But the city needed me too. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down, unsure which call I should answer.
